Paul Hossack (PS2, PSP, DS, PC, iOS) |series = ''[[FIFA (video game series)|FIFA]]'' |engine = |version = 1.04 (Xbox 360, PS3) |released = {{vgrelease|AUS=1 October 2009[http://www.xboxworld.com.au/news/ea-announces-fifa-10-release-date.htm Australian release date for FIFA 10] xboxworld.com.au}}{{vgrelease|EU=2 October 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.eagames.co.uk/news/read/ea-sports-reveals-release-date-for-fifa-10/ |title=EA SPORTS Reveals Release Date For FIFA 10 |publisher=Eagames.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}}}}{{vgrelease|NA=20 October 2009{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5334596/fifa-10-delayed-a-few-weeks|title=FIFA 10 Delayed A Few Weeks (Update)|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=11 August 2009|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|accessdate=11 August 2009}}}}
'''iOS'''
{{vgrelease|INT=2 October 2009[http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/iPhone/FIFA+10+(iPhone)/news.asp?c=15824 FIFA 10 kicks off on iPhone October 2] pocketgamer.co.uk}} |genre = [[Sports game|Sports]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] |ratings = {{vgratings|ESRB=E|PEGI=3+|OFLC=G}} |platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Wii]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation Portable|PSP]], [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]], [[Java ME]] |media = [[Optical disc]], all systems except iOS, mobile phone ([[download]]) and Nintendo DS ([[Nintendo DS Game Card|Game Card]]) |misc |requirements = |input = [[Gamepads]], [[Keyboard (computing)|Keyboard]], [[Mouse (computing)|Mouse]] (menu only), [[Multitouch]] ([[Nintendo DS|NDS]]) }} '''''FIFA 10''''' ('''''FIFA Soccer 10''''' in [[North America]]) is the 17th title in [[Electronic Arts]]' ''[[FIFA (video game series)|FIFA]]'' series of [[Association football|football]] [[video game]]s. Developed by [[EA Canada]], it was published by Electronic Arts worldwide under the [[EA Sports]] label. It was released on 2 October 2009 in Europe, 30 September in Australia and 20 October 2009 in North America. It is available for the [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Wii]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ea.com/news/ea-fifa-soccer-10-in-stores-now |title=EA's FIFA Soccer 10 In Stores Now Throughout North America |publisher=Electronic Arts |date=20 October 2009 |accessdate=21 October 2009 }} Handheld versions of the game were also released for the [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[PlayStation Portable]], and [[mobile phones]]. The demo of ''FIFA 10'' appeared on Xbox 360, PlayStation3, and PC on 10 September in Europe, on 11 September in Australia, and on 17 September in North America. The playable teams were [[Chelsea F.C|Chelsea]], [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] and [[Chicago Fire S.C.|Chicago Fire]]. The stadia used in the demo were [[Wembley Stadium]] (Xbox 360 version), and FIWC Stadium (PlayStation 3 version). The demo offered friendly matches with half lengths of three real-time minutes. As well as playing a friendly match, the demo allows users to upload created in-game videos and screenshots to EA Football World.[http://www.incgamers.com/News/18218/fifa-10-demo-detailed FIFA 10 Demo Detailed], incgamers.com The tagline for the game is "How big can football get?", and "Let's FIFA 10". Commentary is available in 12 different languages, with each language boasting around 25,000 phrases. The English version features British commentators Andy Gray and Martin Tyler. ''FIFA 10'' is the second version of the game to sponsor a football club. Along with football magazine ''[[FourFourTwo]]'', ''FIFA 10'' is the co-sponsor of English [[Football League One|League One]] club [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]]. The ''FIFA 10'' logo appears on the front of the team's away shirt and on the back of the home shirt.{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/5323324/football-game-sponsoring-football-team |title=Football Game Sponsoring Football Team |last=Plunkett |first=Luke |date=27 July 2009 |work=[[Kotaku]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=5 August 2009 }}[http://www.easports.com/blogs/fifa/offthebench/post/slug/fifa-10-sponsors-swindon-town FIFA 10 Sponsors Swindon Town], easports.com It is the first ''FIFA'' game to do so since ''[[FIFA 07]]'', which sponsored [[Accrington Stanley]] for the 2007â08 season. [http://www.teenfi.com/competitions/Win+A+Copy+of+FIFA+07-465.html EA Sports Announce Accrington Stanley FC Sponsorship], teenfi.com ==Manager Mode== [[Manager (football)|Manager]] Mode enables the player to take charge of any club in any of ''FIFA 10'''s featured leagues. The Manager Mode has been revamped for ''FIFA 10'', with many previous issues and criticisms addressed. EA has claimed that over 50 key improvements have been made to the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions.[http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/20462/FIFA-10-UK-Cover-Athletes-Unveiled/ FIFA 10 UK Cover Athletes Unveiled], teamxbox.com Among these improvements are:{{cite web|url=http://fifasoccerblog.com/blog/fsb-exclusive-manager-mode-qa-with-marcel-kuhn/|title=Manager Mode Q&A With Marcel Kuhn|last=Davies|first=Chris|date=17 June 2009|work=FIFA Soccer Blog|publisher=Kitana Media Network|accessdate=21 July 2009}} ===Changes to gameplay=== The "Total Football Experience" is a new feature in which football news from around the Manager Mode world is visible, including player transfers, fixtures and results in foreign leagues. A new "[[Assistant Manager]]" can be used to take care of the team's line-up and to rotate the squad based on importance of the upcoming match. For example, if the next match is against a low rated team, he will make sure that players normally on the bench will start the match. [[Exhibition game|Pre-season friendlies]] have been introduced to the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions of the game, as a chance to flatten out any wrinkles in a team's lineup before the domestic season begins. Results for simulated matches are more heavily based on team strength and do not appear to be as "random" as has been the case in the past. This results in more realistic performances and eliminates instances where stronger clubs would be fighting relegation and clubs with weaker players were winning the league. Non-player clubs also now rotate players more often based on factors such as fatigue, player form, and the relative importance of a match, so the lineup for a top team in the early rounds of a domestic cup may consist of less-able and younger players as opposed to a full-strength squad. The names of the "generic" stadiums can be changed in Manager Mode to reflect the name of the player's club's home ground. [[Image:FIFA 10 E3 2009 screenshot.jpg|thumb|left|300px|An in-game screenshot highlighting the improved transfer system in Manager Mode.]] ====Finances==== All financial matters are based less on a [[sponsor (commercial)|team sponsor]] and more on the club's [[board of directors]], who provide two overall budgets: The wage budget, a yearly amount for paying players, and the club budget, for buying and selling players as well as making other improvements to the club. There is a "Board Difficulty" setting, which determines the financial generosity of the board. The [[transfer (football)|transfer system]] has been made more authentic, as money is no longer the monopolizing factor in acquiring a player. The acceptance of an offer will be based on factors such as the number of players in your squad in the same position, and the promise of higher-level competition outside the domestic league, such as the [[Europa League]] or [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. Furthermore, obtaining a player will be more realistically prolonged as other clubs may also attempt to sign the same player. Bids can be submitted for several different players simultaneously, and if the clubs accept, the manager has the choice of which, if any, of the players to ultimately sign. ====Players==== The "Player Experience and Growth System" has changed. The manual experience growth from ''[[FIFA 08]]'' and ''[[FIFA 09]]'' has been abolished; player growth will now be determined by in-game performance, demands placed on the player, and achievements based on the player's particular position. There are three categories for gaining experience: "mental", "physical", and "skill". Younger players with higher potential will gain experience much faster, and each player will have an individual growth point, which in turn promises more authentic player growth patterns. A "Live Season" feature has been implemented within Manager Mode, whereby a player's "form" rises and falls based on performance (within Manager Mode itself rather than real-world events). He will receive a temporarily higher or lower rating along with temporarily higher or lower stats, to reflect this. Fictional players that are added to Manager Mode by the game itself now have regionalised names, so for example a player from [[Brazil]] will not have an English-sounding name. ==Virtual Pro== "Virtual Pro" allows the player to create a footballer and take him through the four Be a Pro seasons, include him in the Manager Mode career, use him in Kick off, Tournament, and Lounge mode, as well as using him in the Arena. Game Face has also been added to ''FIFA 10'' as in other EA Sports games, where gamers can create their Game Face on the web at easports.com or easportsfootball.co.uk, then download them into the game. Once a Game Face character is created, he can then be applied to the player in game. Faces can be changed on the web any time. The game face is used as the player's avatar in online play. Players can also grow their players attributes and player traits, celebrations, and kit can be unlocked to make the player realistic and unique. A created player can also be taken online to play with friends in the Fifa Clubs mode. ==Stadia== The list of stadia and weather conditions for each one were announced on 27 August 2009. The game features 50 stadiums, including most of the larger stadiums from Europe's most prominent leagues, such as the [[Allianz Arena]], [[Camp Nou]], [[Emirates Stadium]], [[Anfield]], [[Old Trafford]], [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] and [[San Siro]], and as well as a range of generic stadia and practice arenas.[http://www.easportsfootball.co.uk/news/item/file/FIFA_10_Stadiums FIFA 10 Stadia Revealed], eafootballworld.com [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]'s [[Santiago BernabÃ©u Stadium|Santiago BernabÃ©u]] was made available as a free download on launch day.{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/ruttski/status/3389798645|title=David Rutter announces Bernabeu as DLC|accessdate=27 August 2009}} The weather conditions possible in each stadium range from day and night versions of clear to cloudy, rain, or snow. The stadium names of the generic stadiums can however be changed in a special section of the main menu to reflect the name of the users club's homeground if the user chooses to do so. The capacity of each ground is also listed so that a capacity similar to a club's actual stadium capacity can be chosen to make game experience more authentic. ==Ultimate Team== On 1 December 2009, EA Sports announced that the ''Ultimate Team'' game mode expansion that was introduced in ''FIFA 09'' would be released in February 2010 for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] versions of the game. Like the previous version, the mode allows for the creation of a custom team based on the collection of various types of cards. The expansion was released on 25 February 2010,{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} and featured new [[PlayStation Network]] Trophies and [[Xbox Live]] Achievements for ''FIFA 10''. It costs 400 MS Points/$4.99/â¬4.99/Â£3.99.{{cite web|author=Paul Hossack |url=http://www.easportsfootball.co.uk/blogs/offthebench/post/slug/fifa-10-ultimate-team-blog-1-2/ |title=FIFA 10 Ultimate Team Blog #1 |publisher=Easportsfootball.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} The mode is an update to the Ultimate Team mode from ''FIFA 09''. Users who owned the original Ultimate Team were given two free Gold packs after creating their team, along with a date below the teams name to show the year the team was founded. Like the original, each team is given a full team of players to begin with, along with a stadium, emblem and a home and away kit. New players, staff and items can be purchased from the 6 different pack types available, split into three categories(Gold, Silver and Bronze), or by trading with other users by bidding on cards they are opting to sell, offering them deals or buying them for a specific price. The in-game currency is coins, which are awarded for playing games, playing in tournaments or trading with other users. Bonus coins are awarded for completing different requirements, such as winning a game, being awarded Man of the Match and for possession and passing accuracy. The card packs for Ultimate Team still have basic Bronze Packs (500 coins), Silver Packs (2500 coins) and Gold Packs (5000 Coins), but now also have a bonus pack in each category, called Premium Packs, costing slightly more coins (Bronze cost 750, Silver cost 3250 and Gold cost 7500) but giving 3 rare cards, instead of the 1 given in basic packs. Like the old Ultimate Team, to keep your players on your squad you must give them contracts. However, unlike last year, players who run out of contracts are rendered unplayable until a contract is applied to them, rather that being removed from your team altogether. Contracts can be found in packs or bought in the trading section. Unlike the old Ultimate Team, players can now store an unlimited amount of players, stadiums, staff members, kits and emblems, to use whenever they need to. The Trading section has also been improved, allowing improved searching and a watch list, to keep track of certain items. ==Covers== Each regional version of ''FIFA 10'' features different players on the cover with [[Wayne Rooney]] being on most. The [[United Kingdom]] and [[Republic of Ireland]] covers feature [[Theo Walcott]], [[Frank Lampard]] and Wayne Rooney; the [[Australia]]n cover features Wayne Rooney and [[Tim Cahill]],{{cite web|url=http://au.fourfourtwo.com/news/111107,cahill-is-fifa-2010-cover-star.aspx |title=FIFA 10 Australian cover |publisher=Au.fourfourtwo.com |date=2009-08-28 |accessdate=2010-02-21}} the [[New Zealand]] cover features Wayne Rooney and Frank Lampard, the [[Germany|German]] cover features [[Bastian Schweinsteiger]] and Wayne Rooney;{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5330407/ea-unveils-fifa-10-box-art-release-date|title=EA Unveils FIFA 10 Box Art, Release Date|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|date=5 August 2009|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|accessdate=5 August 2009}} the [[Italy|Italian]] cover features [[Ronaldinho]] and [[Giorgio Chiellini]];{{cite web|url=http://mediasrv01.eaeurope.eu/images/images/216689-FIFA_10_ITA_Packart.jpg |title=FIFA 10 Italian cover |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} the [[France|French]] cover features [[Steve Mandanda]], [[Karim Benzema]], and [[Guillaume Hoarau]];{{cite web|url=http://image.jeuxvideo.com/images/jaquettes/00028449/jaquette-fifa-10-xbox-360-cover-avant-g.jpg |title=FIFA 10 French cover |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} the [[Spain|Spanish]] cover features Karim Benzema and [[Xavi]];{{cite web|url=http://194.169.225.105/images/images/217647-FIFApackshot.jpg |title=FIFA 10 Spanish cover |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} the [[Poland|Polish]] version features Wayne Rooney and [[Robert Lewandowski]];{{cite web|url=http://www.igol.pl/images/articles/fifa1003.jpg |title=FIFA 10 Polish cover |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] version features Frank Lampard and [[SimÃ£o Sabrosa|SimÃ£o]];[http://m.mygames.pt/MediaCenter/media/images/ezine/FIFA10genKEYpor.jpg/ FIFA 10 Portuguese cover]{{dead link|date=February 2010}} the [[Russia]]n version features [[Sergei Semak]]; the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] version features Wayne Rooney and [[BalÃ¡zs DzsudzsÃ¡k]];{{cite web|url=http://www.electronicarts.hu/images/packshots/thumbs/217791.hp2-3.jpg/ |title=FIFA 10 Hungarian cover |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} and the [[North America]]n version features Frank Lampard, [[CuauhtÃ©moc Blanco]] and [[Sacha Kljestan]]. ==Leagues== There are 30 leagues and over 500 teams in the game, as well as 41 national teams. New to ''FIFA 10'' is the [[Russian Premier League]], which is not featured in the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions.[http://www.fifainformer.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=136&Itemid=62 No Russian League for PS3/360] fifainformer.com Unlike previous versions of ''FIFA'', the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] is included as a fully licensed national team.[http://worthplaying.com/article/2009/9/21/news/68612/ 'FIFA 10' Adds Dutch National Team] worthplaying.com Due to promotion/relegation and other league expansions, there are 46 teams that were not included in ''FIFA 09'', including 25 that have never appeared in a ''FIFA'' game before.[http://www.thesportsgamer.com/?p=271 New squads in 'FIFA 10'] thesportsgamer.com The leagues in FIFA 10 are:[http://www.eurogamer.ro/articles/fifa-10-leagues-echipe-campionate- FIFA 10 - LicenÈe], eurogamer.ro {{col-start}} {{col-break}} * {{flagicon|AUS}} '''Australia''' **[[A-League]] * {{flagicon|AUT}} '''Austria''' **[[Austrian Football Bundesliga|Austrian Bundesliga]] * {{flagicon|BEL}} '''Belgium''' **[[Belgian Pro League]] * {{flagicon|BRA}} '''Brazil''' **[[Campeonato Brasileiro SÃ©rie A|Brazil Serie A]] * {{flagicon|CZE}} '''Czech Republic''' **[[Gambrinus liga]] * {{flagicon|DEN}} '''Denmark''' **[[Danish Superliga]] * {{flagicon|ENG}} '''England''' **[[Premier League]] **[[Football League Championship|Championship]] **[[Football League One|League One]] **[[Football League Two|League Two]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} '''France''' **[[Ligue 1]] **[[Ligue 2]] * {{flagicon|GER}} '''Germany''' **[[FuÃball-Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] **[[2. FuÃball-Bundesliga|2.Bundesliga]] * {{flagicon|IRL}} '''Ireland''' **[[League of Ireland Premier Division|Ireland Premier]] * {{flagicon|ITA}} '''Italy''' **[[Serie A]] **[[Serie B]] {{col-break}} * {{flagicon|KOR}} '''South Korea''' **[[K-League]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} '''Mexico''' **[[Primera DivisiÃ³n de MÃ©xico|Primera DivisiÃ³n]] * {{flagicon|NED}} '''Netherlands''' **[[Eredivisie]] * {{flagicon|NOR}} '''Norway''' **[[Tippeligaen]] * {{flagicon|POL}} '''Poland''' **[[Ekstraklasa]] * {{flagicon|POR}} '''Portugal''' **[[Portuguese Liga]] * {{flagicon|SCO}} '''Scotland''' **[[Scottish Premier League|Scottish Premier]] * {{flagicon|ESP}} '''Spain''' **[[La Liga]], [[Segunda DivisiÃ³n]] * {{flagicon|SWE}} '''Sweden''' **[[Allsvenskan]] * {{flagicon|SWI}} '''Switzerland''' **[[Swiss Super League]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} '''Turkey''' **[[SÃ¼per Lig]] * {{flagicon|USA}} '''United States''' **[[Major League Soccer]] {{col-end}} ==Soundtrack== The ''FIFA 10'' soundtrack album was announced by EA Sports on July 31, 2009 and features 34 songs.{{cite web|url=http://www.ea.com/music/the-official-fifa-soccer-10-soundtrack |title=The Official FIFA Soccer 10 Soundtrack |publisher=Ea.com |date= |accessdate=2010-02-21}} The Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions feature the following tracks, including five not included on the soundtrack album, as marked below."Miss You", "Favela Rock", "Head Straight", "Birthday Bash", and "Science of Fear" are featured in-game only - they are not on the ''FIFA 10'' soundtrack album [http://investor.ea.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=399098 EA Announces Fall Music Line Up for Sports Franchises] Electronic Arts Inc. {{col-start}} {{col-break}} * [[Adiam Dymott]] â "Miss You" * Afrobots â "Favela Rock" * [[Alex Metric]] â "Head Straight" * [[The Answering Machine]] â "It's Over! It's Over! It's Over!" * [[Auletta (band)|Auletta]] â "Meine Stadt" * [[Balkan Beat Box]] feat. Tomer Yosef and [[Sameh Zakout|Saz]] â "Ramallah Tel Aviv" * [[BLK JKS]] â "Lakeside" * [[Bomba EstÃ©reo]] â "Fuego" * [[Buraka Som Sistema]] feat. Pongolove â "Kalemba (Wegue - Wegue)" * [[The BPA]] feat. [[Ashley Beedle]] â "Should I Stay or Should I Blow" * [[Casiokids]] â "Fot i Hose" * [[Children Collide]] â "Skeleton Dance" * [[Crookers]] feat. [[Esau Mwamwaya|The Very Best]], Two Fingers, and [[Marina Ribatski|Marina Gasolina]] â "Birthday Bash" * [[Cut Off Your Hands]] â "Happy As Can Be" * [[Dananananaykroyd]] â "Black Wax" * [[Datarock]] â "Give It Up" * [[The Enemy (UK band)|The Enemy]] â "Be Somebody" * [[Fabri Fibra]] â "Donna Famosa" * [[Fidel Nadal (reggae musician)|Fidel Nadal]] â "International Love" * [[Los Fabulosos Cadillacs]] â "La Luz del Ritmo" {{col-break}} * [[Macaco (band)|Macaco]] â "Hacen Falta Dos" * [[Major Lazer]] feat. Mr. Lexx and [[Santigold]] â "Hold the Line" * MÃ¡rcio Local â "Soul do Samba" * [[Matt & Kim]] â "Daylight (Troublemaker Remix feat. [[De La Soul]])" * [[Metric (band)|Metric]] â "Gold Guns Girls" * [[Mexican Institute of Sound]] â "Alocatel" * [[Nneka (singer)|Nneka]] feat. [[Wesley Williams]] â "Kangpe" * [[Passion Pit]] â "Moth's Wings" * [[Peter Bjorn and John]] â "[[Nothing to Worry About]]" * [[Pint Shot Riot]] â "Not Thinking Straight" * [[Playing for Change]] â "War (No More Trouble)" * Rocky Dawuni â "Download the Revolution" * [[RÃ¶yksopp]] â "It's What I Want" * [[SoShy]] â "Dorothy" * [[The Temper Trap]] â "[[Science of Fear]]" * [[The Whitest Boy Alive]] â "1517" * [[Tommy Sparks]] â "[[She's Got Me Dancing]]" * [[Wyclef Jean]] â "MVP Kompa" * [[Zap Mama]] â "Vibrations" {{col-end}} ==Reception== ===Commercial=== According to EA, the latest edition in ''FIFA'' series is the fastest selling sports game ever in Europe, selling 1.7 million copies in its first week. ''FIFA 10'' sales could rise as much as 30 percent year-over-year in Europe, making FIFA the most profitable EA Sports title, thanks to its global audience and lower license costs, compared to the ''[[Madden NFL|Madden]]'' series.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6232101.html|title=FIFA 10 Europe's fastest selling sports game ever|last=Walton|first=Mark|date=7 October 2009|work=GameSpot UK|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} It is the biggest All Formats No1 launch since ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'', generating 48% more sales than its predecessor, ''[[FIFA 09]]'' edging past ''[[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chart-track.co.uk/?i=700&s=1111|title=FIFA 10 Scores BIG|last=|first=|date=5 October 2009|work=|publisher=[[Chart-Track]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} It has sold over 10 million units since launch.[http://www.gamespot.com/news/6262120.html EA's full-year loss hits $677 million, FIFA 10 sells 10 million] GameSpot, 11 May 2010. Retrieved 3 April 2011 ===Critical reception=== {{VG Reviews | GR = 90%{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps3/960428-fifa-soccer-10/index.html|title=FIFA Soccer 10 for PlayStation 3 - GameRankings|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} | MC = 91/100{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ps3/fifasoccer10|title=FIFA Soccer 10 (ps3) reviews at Metacritic.com|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} | Allgame = {{Rating|4|5}}[http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=69769 FIFA Soccer 10 - Overview - allgame] | IGN = 9/10[http://uk.ps3.ign.com/articles/103/1035159p1.html FIFA 10 Review - PlayStation 3 Review at IGN] | GSpot = 9/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/ps3/sports/fifasoccer10/review.html|title=FIFA Soccer 10 Review for PlayStation 3 - GameSpot|last=Cocker|first=Guy|date=6 October 2009|work=GameSpot UK|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} | ONM = 84% | 1UP = B[http://www.1up.com/games/ps3/fifa-soccer-10/review FIFA Soccer 10 PS3 Reviews] | EuroG = 9/10[http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/fifa-10-review?page=3 FIFA 10 Review - Xbox 360 - Page 3 | Eurogamer.net] | GT = 9.1/10[http://www.gametrailers.com/game/fifa-soccer-10/11556 FIFA Soccer 10 Video Game | GameTrailers.com] }} ''FIFA 10'' has received high critical acclaim, with a 91% aggregate rating at [[Metacritic]]{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ps3/fifasoccer10|title=FIFA Soccer 10 (ps3) reviews at Metacritic.com|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} and a 90% aggregate rating on [[GameRankings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps3/960428-fifa-soccer-10/index.html|title=FIFA Soccer 10 for PlayStation 3 - GameRankings|last=|first=|date=|work=|publisher=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} The first review was a 9/10 from ''[[PlayStation Official Magazine]]'' (UK), commenting "This not only plays the best on-the-pitch football of any ''FIFA'' title, but it has an incredibly smart and compelling way of tying it all together, too. Brilliant, again." ''[[IGN]] UK'' gave the game a rating of 9.3/10 for both PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions commenting "One of the most refined, polished and compelling takes on the beautiful game â and arguably of any given sport. While this year's improvements might seem slight on paper, each one is perfectly pitched and works together to create an experience that's an improvement on last year's game in every conceivable way."{{cite web|url=http://uk.xbox360.ign.com/articles/102/1028164p1.html|title=IGN: FIFA Soccer 10 Review|last=Robinson|first=Martin|date=24 September 2009|work=IGN UK|publisher=IGN|accessdate=19 October 2009}} ''[[GameSpot]]'' gave it a 9/10, saying "''FIFA 10'' offers the best gameplay in the series' history and includes even more features and game modes to boot." It also earned the "Editor's Choice Award" for both PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 versions.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/ps3/sports/fifasoccer10/review.html|title=FIFA Soccer 10 Review for PlayStation 3 - GameSpot|last=Cocker|first=Guy|date=6 October 2009|work=GameSpot UK|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=19 October 2009}} The [[Nintendo Wii]] version was given an 84% rating by ''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]'' praising the exclusive art style and game boosters. Shortly after release, the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions of ''FIFA 10'' came in for some criticism for containing various [[Software bug|bugs]], mostly related to the game's Manager Mode. A downloadable [[patch (computing)|patch]] was issued in mid October to fix issues ranging from players being sold without permission to connection problems online.[http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/new-fifa-10-patch-this-week-ea-keen-to-address-remaining-issues New FIFA 10 patch this week, EA keen to address remaining issues], eurogamer.net ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://fifa.easports.com/home.action Official site] * [http://easportsfootball.com Official ''FIFA 10'' community site] {{Football video games by Electronic Arts}} {{EA Sports 10 games}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fifa 10}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:FIFA (video game series)|2009]] [[Category:Electronic Arts games]] [[Category:EA Sports games]] [[Category:Association football video games]] [[Category:Electronic sports games]] [[Category:Sports video games with career mode]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Mobile phone games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Wii Wi-Fi games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[ar:ÙÙÙØ§ 10]] [[ca:FIFA 10]] [[da:FIFA 10]] [[es:FIFA 10]] [[fa:ÙÛÙØ§ Û±Û°]] [[fr:FIFA 10]] [[ko:FIFA 10]] [[hr:FIFA 10]] [[it:FIFA 10]] [[nl:FIFA 10]] [[ja:FIFA 10]] [[no:FIFA 10]] [[pl:FIFA 10]] [[pt:FIFA 10]] [[ro:FIFA 10]] [[ru:FIFA 10]] [[simple:FIFA 10]] [[fi:FIFA 10]] [[sv:FIFA 10]] [[tr:FIFA 10]] [[uk:FIFA 10]] [[zh:FIFA 10]]
